description.text:
The 5 in 1 charger for 1s lipo is very nice for micro FPV quadcopter (Tiny Whoop style), 5 lipos can be charged at the same time by usb input or 2-4S big lipo.
I got one together with KingKong Tiny 7, however it doesn't have a case, so I designed one.

The printed result doesn't fit perfectly (too tight, text too small to read), but it serves purpose.

Warning: it becomes too hot when using lipo as input!

comments.text: Does this also has the holes for the tiny6 battery's? I love the design but not sure if the smaller battery will fit.
comments.author: roppers

comments.text: yes, small connectors are also accessible.
comments.author: roppers

title: dell power plug cable strap holder pin

description.text:
This is a replacement for the plastic pin that holds the elastic band on a a Dell Laptop power supply.
This way of storing the cable is great, and this print replaces a broken or lost pin.

Print it, insert it.
There should be no need to tweak it, but you get the openscad file by the way (I measured it with a caliper from another Dell Laptop power supply). More seriously, you probably want to consider a minimum layer print time (as I forgot), since the head is so small that it can melt as a whole on the end of the printing process. It happened to me but the pin was still usable and held the elastic band nicely. I just used a lighter and metal rule to reshape it slightly to make it a bit more sexy... This is my first useful printed part :) Update: sorry, I just realized that soehler already made this very specific thing (thingiverse is amazing!) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17007

comments.text: Been trying to print this on my CTC dual and the bottom starts great but then epically fails as it goes up lol
comments.author: chickey

comments.text:
Try to lower temperature to the maximum extent. The head is very tricky because it is so small. You really do not want to over-extrude either. I suspect the default slicer settings may not be that good, esp. for the temperature.
This object is hard to print, but it is a good way to know one's printer better :)
comments.author: chickey

comments.text: Thanks a lot for posting this design, this was very helpful to me!
comments.author: __Vincent__

comments.text: Where can I purchase one of these? Thanks
comments.author: pvwyss

comments.text:
Well... I found none on the real-life market, so that's why I designed & 3D printed it!
You could have it printed on an online 3D printing service, but it would probably cost a lot (may be more than what Dell would charge if it sells it nowadays)... may be check with a nearby fablab?
comments.author: pvwyss

title: Playerunknown's Battlegrounds Frying Pan Fidget Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Been playing and enjoying this game a lot. I decided to design one of these popular fidget spinners based on one of the most know item inside the game; The Frying Pan :)

With 100% scale I had to use a vice to force the bearings in (not necessarily a bad thing) but you may want to add 1-2% to make the installation easier. Uses 608 bearings. You need four of them. Ceramic ones work the best on the center. Happy printing!

ps. Didn't have darker filament at hand. I'll print a sample with black soon and post a picture.

Update 04.06.2017:
Added the finger holds, both with and without text. Also added the spinner model without text for a cleaner print. Note that the finger pieces are different so you need to print both halves. Note! I haven't printed these yet myself!

Yes

author: NandN

description.text:
A differential for the brilliant OpenRC F1 car by Barspin.

https://youtu.be/OVFahlVHfgs
https://youtu.be/vIPqNfZuDnc

It replaces the stock gear. The right rear wheel will need to be replaced with a front wheel with bearings. The lock nut for the right side needs to be replaced with the one in this set so that the bearings don't lock up.

Ball bearings:
https://www.banggood.com/Wltoys-A949-A959-A969-A979-8x12x3_5mm-Ball-Bearing-4Pcs-p-937936.html?p=HD240528697332015103

Bearings01.STL - Printable bearings if you don't have ball bearings.
Diff01.STL - Differential with 40 tooth spur gear.
Diff02.STL - Differential with 46 tooth spur gear.

comments.text: Do you need to put little pins though the holes in the small gears to locate them in the spur properly ?
comments.author: Car69meuk

comments.text: Works great! For the 2017 updated version of the OpenRC F1 I just added an additional bearing on the outside of the rim to compensate for the longer axle.
comments.author: torbjell

comments.text: Thanks so much for this. Brilliant design.
comments.author: kelad

comments.text: Hello,
comments.author: Saiteik

comments.text: Hi, I think I have the same issue, I have printed versions on two different printers and both have the same difficulty with the drive side. I can hold the spur gear and turn the left wheel freely but the right wheel does not turn. It appears to be the bevel gear that fits inside the wheel is not meshing with the properly with the spider gears, not sure why as they turn freely enough when turning the left wheel but when the right wheel and bevel gear is driving the spider gears, they lock up.
comments.author: Saiteik

comments.text: They're not perfect, but they should mesh fine. I guess it can vary from printer to printer. When I print a diff it usually feels rough at first due to the intricacies of printing and sometimes micro plastic debris and occasional micro stringing between some teeth. I like to hold one wheel and spin the motor for a few seconds with a new diff and that usually beds them in. The ones I have on my two F1 cars feel and look well meshed.
comments.author: Saiteik

comments.text: I have tried to break them in by locking either side while having the motor rotate. I ended up chewing through one of the beveled sides (rim hub) and significantly wore down the spider gears. After further inspection I believe the problem lies with the positioning of the spider gears on the spur. I actually did a few things to correct this as I do not believe it is my printer. I have the Original Prusa i3 MK2s and printed accurate calibration cubes. I modified the rim hub to be shorter and wider near the bearing so it can grab more rim. I also changed the spur to accommodate 3 spider gears rather than 5. I believe this will reduce friction load allowing for easier slipping of the diff. I will update you on how it goes, honestly I commend you for the engineering effort done to make this diff fit in such an incredibly small area.
comments.author: tahustvedt

comments.text: Did you lube the gears before running them in?
comments.author: Saiteik

comments.text: Nope, however even if I did they just didn't align so I doubt it would have been an improvement.
comments.author: tahustvedt

comments.text: Just a little bit of lube will really help. They melt from the friction.
comments.author: Saiteik

comments.text: This is what it should look like. This one spins very smoothly and easily since it has been run in. There's a reason why I said they need lubrication in the instructions: https://youtu.be/OVFahlVHfgs
comments.author: tahustvedt

comments.text: Is the gear that goes on the wheel side meant to slot into the gaps on the wheel rim?
comments.author: ChrisMayhew

comments.text: Yes.
comments.author: ChrisMayhew

comments.text: Mine doesn't seem to slot inside, just seems to sit on the edges of the wheel rim.
comments.author: tahustvedt

comments.text: I didn't design that rim. If the rim doesn't have the same dimensions as the stock front rim then it won't fit.
comments.author: ChrisMayhew

comments.text: Ok, Well i'll give it another go once I've repaired a few parts
comments.author: tahustvedt

comments.text: Hi! Very nice job!
comments.author: dnlsrs

comments.text: Doesn't your slicer have the option to separate the pieces?
comments.author: dnlsrs

comments.text: Sorry. I'm new at this
comments.author: tahustvedt

comments.text: Under the "Mesh" menu select "Separate Connected Surfaces" while the part is selected.
comments.author: dnlsrs

comments.text: WOW! Thank you very much!
comments.author: tahustvedt

comments.text: Well done! What is the big difference between the 40 and 46 teeth version? I assume the 40 teeth version is more suitable for a larger nozzle? What material did you use? Nylon or plain PLA?
comments.author: Marcel_X

comments.text: Both are the same tooth pitch. The 46 t gear is there to provide more gear ratios to play with. One of my other things is a set of pinions for this car. If you want to slow the car down or you have a very fast motor youcan install the 46t diff and the 9t pinion and you slow it down to 56%.
comments.author: Marcel_X

comments.text: Thanks for the quick reply! Do you have a recommendation for the material? Plain PLA, Colorfabb XT, a co-polyester or something else? Just did some research and it seems that nylon (even though very strong) is a bit to flexible for high torque gears.
comments.author: tahustvedt

comments.text: I made all mine from PLA. I like to design my stuff so that PLA works well, if possible. That way it's going to work for everyone.
comments.author: Marcel_X

comments.text:
Wow, i didn't think anyone would manage to make one given the tiny space you're working with! Well done.
Will have to give this a go soon.

description.text:
I don't know why dollar coins get a bad rap, I love to keep a bunch of them in my car to pay for the drive through. I was using pill bottles to hold them, but when I got a 3D printer an idea was born! In the first version, the top was held on only by friction, but I found it popping off as the container rolled around in my car door cargo area, so I made a new version where the cap has a secure "twist lock". Hold one $25 Roll. Enjoy!

6/5/17 -- Added additional version of top embossed with "$25"
7/5 -- Updated with thicker walls after having one of my containers break. Also the cap fits tighter now -- when first fitting the top and bottom together they will be extremely tight, but after a few twists it loosens up and will be a very secure fit.

description.text:
This adapter is to fit cheap H7 led heahlight on the KLR.

Print on ABS/PETG or PC for temp tolerance.

How to use:

  1. Print it
  2. Remove the headlight cowling from the KLR (the 2 phillips and the 4 M6 bolts).
  3. Disconnect the headlight and turn signals
  4. Remove the light cover
  5. Raise the light lock
  6. Remove the old light bulb
  7. Put the adapter with the widthest part to the front. There is only 1 way to put there.
  8. Lock the adapter in the right location
  9. Remove the OEM adapter from your led bulb
  10. Put the led into the adapter. Be carefull that led bulb have 2 marks, one is bigger.
  11. Once enter, turn the led bulb in clockwise direction until stop it.

You could need to cut the cover in order to fit the led heat sink.

description.text:
A parametric set of fingers that you can fasten to the wall with double-stick-tape. Holds stuff for you.
Also does double-duty as a filament retract test object -- only one you can use.

So yeah.  Another cable holder that looks like creepy fingers.  Yawn.  
But wait!  Look at the openSCAD file!
I've been playing around with the hull() command, and I'm convinced it could be the center of a very powerful modelling strategy.  In particular, the sequentialHull() function in this file is great.  
You just pass it a list of objects and it hulls them together pairwise.  The fingers here were created from a stubby cylinder and three spheres.  The cylinder gives you a thick round attachment point and the (flattened) spheres define the finger.  Easy-peasy, organic shapes/paths/etc.  
Where this strategy shines is the: "I need a hole here and another there, and something to hold it together" scenario.  Play with the code, you'll see what I mean.

title: Nerf 61 Shot Absolver for 4" PVC Fittings

description.text:
Are you tired of shooting less than 50 darts at a single time? Do you have a singled drain blaster that your friends are making you change? Then this is probably the absolver for you. If you've got the air power, this absolver will allow you to rain foamy disrespect upon your friends and foes alike. Design to fit inside a 4" PVC fitting with only mild sanding in the corners, this will be a perfect addition to any air-powered loadout.

Please note, this is still a fairly early prototype and needs some testing. As usual, barrel diameter is .490" compared to .485" in CPVC.

Update: I've now included a very experimental print for an adapter to go from this absolver to 2" PVC.

title: Replacement Solidoodle 3 belt idler pulley holder

description.text:
This is a replacement for the idler pulley holders that come mounted on a solidoodle 3. I don't know if it will work on other versions since I only have a 3. These are made to use 5mm rods about 40mm long. Thankfully you can buy a bag of 10 off amazon for like $7. It's definitely better than using those m5 bolts that come it in it normally, it you're going to replace your belts with GT2s like I did.
All you need to do is mirror the part in order to get the other side. Just use a normal socket head m3 screw to hold it in place, you don't need the screws that held the old ones in place. Also the old ones have lock tight holding them on so be careful not to strip it on the way out.
Print it on your build area so it looks like a U when seen from above.

I made this modular skyscraper for a school project and decided to share it. The building is made up of two level designs and a roof. By printing the Building Level files you can customize the height. All of the levels and the roof fit together. The Building files are three different sizes of a complete version.

Print without supports, rafts are optional.
In general printing without rafts will lead to slightly messy undersides of buildings, however printing this way will make post-print easier.

I recommend printing the full buildings (Building 1, Building 2, and Building 3) scaled down as they are large. I printed them at 40 percent, but that was because I use a smaller printer.

I recommend printing the individual levels at full size and then connecting them.

The wallet I designed for my friend. Inspiration was from his very disorganized wallet, that was ripping from all the coins he kept in it. Basically, the hollow portion underneath stores the credit card; the hold provides a place for the user's thumb to slide cards out. On top, there is a closed-off compartment to store coins (specifically Canadian, but can be used for any type of coin) The slider simply slides in so that coins do not fall out whenever, since the top is open. This is my first design ever, I used Fusion 360 and I am very open to feedback and potential improvements. Thanks!

These were created by 6th grade students, designed to hold a small flameless LED tea light. Don't use a candle with a flame!

Some models need support or brim.

Baseball designed by Rory Keegan https://tinkercad.com/things/a5yvplv0JB1
Unicorn by Beth https://tinkercad.com/things/6pv3GBXd8T8
NGSS

This project was part of a 6th grade electricity unit. After learning about how LEDs work students created a printable mode that incorporates a flameless LED candle. Students could make a model that holds the candle, or use translucent plastic to make a model with the candle inside.
If students remixed someone else's design they needed cite the original source of the model so they could be properly credited (see above).

Students needed to make a model that would incorporate a flameless LED tea light.
The LED tea light is a cylinder 40 mm in diameter and 40 mm high.  If putting the LED inside the model a cavity large enough has to be created.

Flameless LED tea lights can be purchased in packs of 2 or 3 dozen for less that 50 cents a piece. They are also available in different colors.
Translucent plastic is helpful and gives the students more options when designing. This type of plastic is sometimes described as "transparent," "clear," or "natural."

title: Anet A8 y-belt Improved tensioner with thumbscrew

description.text:
After trying several belt tensioners I decided I liked the Improved Y-belt Tensioner by Freemark the best, but there were a few things I thought could be better. The placement of the bearing was better than the tensioner by CH35C0 but I really liked the thumbscrew on the design by CH35C0.

The thumbscrew not only makes it easier to adjust tension, it also means the acrylic is less likely to be marred like the metal screws used in the original design by freemark.

Additionally, this splits the parts into 3 separate files, so if you want to print the parts in different colors, like I did, you don't have to edit the file or print parts that aren't going to be used.

Printer:

anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I recommend a wide brim for the main tensioner part unless you know you have excellent bed adhesion. The posts are printed initially as towers and get relatively tall before they join with the top plate. This makes it into a long lever, which was knocked over twice when I was attempting a print before I used a 10mm brim.

I also recommend a wider top, bottom, and sides to give some added support. I went with .2mm all around.

I also want to note that supports are not required and using them, especially with the screw, will probably make it impossible to use.

I'm using the original design for the tensioner from Freemark. I found this was a very tight fit. I personally think this is a good thing but I had to do some sanding to get a clean fit.

Assembly should be pretty self explanatory. The posts fit into the top most square holes where the original bearing mount goes. The top plate goes over the top of the bracket. The plate slides in with the small end facing away from the printer and the screw goes in the screw hole. No additional parts should be required.

This is my very first "design." It's not really fair to say I designed it as I took 2 excellent designs and put them together in TinkerCAD. I am grateful to the original designers and the people who made a free, online tool that resulted in a very easy job making the tensioner I wanted from the best of both designs.

comments.text:
Going to make this, tensioner part first, to see if it fits my older A8. Will report back.
[later]
Good print, but again the screw didn't fit the hole. Going to remake at 92% X and Y.
[even later]
You will need to shrink the screw to 92% in the X and Y and leave the Z 100% to make it fit the plate right.
Also I printed the part the pulley goes on with the broad part down, with support. The first one done vertical failed. 3 shells and 50% fill.
It is a file fit into the two square holes. So expect some fiddle. Other than the screw size annoyance its a real nice part.

  • Fit new holder a get printing!

I was worried about the exposed sides of my SpaceOneFPV Formula 220x so I designed some side plates for it. I did 1mm wall, .8mm Top and Bottom, 20% fill, with a 4mm Brim on a heated bed. title: Flexible Landing Gear for Quadcopter "Crossfire" Version 3

description.text: Further improved version of my flexible landing gear for MikeyB's quadcopter "Crossfire" or my derivate "Crossfire Mini". (Compatibility with Crossfire 2 is about to be tested) After hard landings, even the version 2 of my flexible landing gears broke. I detected and fixed the critical regions, now it's really stable. In comparison to version 1 and 2, it is now printed upside down. The part pointing towards the quadcopter's arms has been redesigned and is now very stable. The flexibility in the "bended double leg" proved successful, so I kept this design. However, the ball at the end had to move because of the "upside down" redesign. The holders for M3.5-M4 nuts are still there. Please adapt their size to fit your nuts! Their distance from the bottom plate has increased such that your screws should stand out at least 12mm (1/2in) from the bottom plate.

description.text: KIM (Kinetic Interactive Machine) is my version of the original ESRA by Brian Patton. Each piece of the original schematics have been slightly altered to give KIM a more "feminine appearance. Most noticeably are the elongated shape of her ears, cheekbones, nose, jawline and eyes. As additional features, I have added false eyelashes and ear "piercings" in which I have inserted store-bought earrings. She is a unique robot and she is also only one creative direction in which one can take the original, amazing design.

KIM's original model, ESRA, was designed by Brian Patton in Google SketchUp. After seeing how he created ESRA, I was inspired to create KIM. Many of the joint pieces, including the jaw links, and eyespacers are the exact same files as the original schematics, only scaled slightly smaller. However, the rest of the pieces, (I.e the eyebrows, ears, nose and cheekbones) were all completely re-designed and sketched to fit the original pieces. Though a long and tedious process, I highly recommend experimenting as much as possible with this sort of creation as it is completely customizable and generally fun to do!

title: Electrical Box for a Chinese 110/220v machine switch

description.text:
I ordered electrical switches from Chinese web sites for use with woodworking equipment. It seems the switches won't mount in North American electrical boxes as the screws are slightly closer together. It's probably an asian or European standard.

I made this box with cut outs for wires, a spot to mount hold downs and a generous ledge around the top that allows me to drill a 1/8" hole where ever needed to mount the Chinese switch.

NOTE: These boxes are NOT going to pass any electrical inspection so don't use them in walls. I use them in equipment but that doesn't have to be inspected so it's not been an issue. Also the box is not grounded (duh, it's plastic). It could be used in household walls for low-voltage applications.

description.text: The plural of block is bloxen. The singular of bloxen is bloxen. This is an interlocking castle block. It's the fundamental defensive model for playing Seej. http://www.s33j.net

No assembly required. Just print it and start playing Seej. Rules for Seej can be found at http://www.s33j.net This bloxen makes a great calibration object for your printer; it's simple enough to print reliably but also has some interesting geometry on the locking mortises underneath. Bloxen are intended to fit together loosely so that your opponent has a sporting chance of knocking down your defenses.

description.text:
If your motor has an M5 screw to mount the props, you can put these spinners on top to route the air nicely around the motor. It is also nice if you put your copter upside down for maintenance or to (un)mount your battery.  
Internally, the M5 bolt of your motor fits over a length of 10mm. The bottom 4mm are additionally larger to make room for a nut. So this spinner was designed for motors where you put on props with a nut on an M5 bolt, which then can stand out further up to 6mm above the nut. You can adjust these metrics in the mesh if it doesn't fit.  
Since the transition from nut to bold when printing layer by layer happens immediately, there should be some support unless your slicing program can handle situations like this very cleverly. I included a version with small internal support which can then be easily be removed with pliers.  
A blender file is included, but it's only a raw mesh, the support being a separate object.

Print the version which includes support, but print it without automatic support, of course. I printed it in 0.2mm layers and a low infill ratio.  
After printing, you can easily remove the support from the actual spinners with pliers. The internal support structure is 4mm tall.

author: mdpminc

title: Soil retaining mesh grill for upside-down planter

description.text:
I decided to make an upside-down planter for suspending pot plants from the roof of the conservatory.  
Having bought a cheap, but nice looking, flower pot from the local garden centre and drilling a hole in the bottom, I decided to add a mesh grill that keeps the soil in.  
The design is fully parametric (if you use the OpenSCAD file), so can be adjusted to suit your own needs. My flower pot has four mouldings in the  base and the grill had to be notched to fit around them.

I printed this in ABS and increased the flow rate to 120%, which gave me the best results. It seems suitably robust but flexible enough to fit around the plant.  
If, unlike me, you don't need the four notches (though it probably won't matter if you leave them), set add_notches to false in the OpenSCAD file.  
Enjoy!

Replacement parts for the Tevo Tarantula 3D printer.

EDIT (17/07/2017): Added CAD files in .DXF and .DAE formats

EDIT (24/01/2028): Fixed the Y mount, which was too big, and corrected the mounting holes for the hot end bracket.

EDIT (28/02/2018):
I've had many discussions with people here on Thingiverse and Facebook regarding these brackets, and I want to clarify that these are not intended as upgrade parts. I call them "replacement brackets" intentionally because they were only meant to be a quick replacement if I broke the original acrylic parts; as a stop-gap only. At the time I modelled them (from the patterns found on grabcad) I wasn't sure how I was going to upgrade my machine so I didn't want to spend the time printing crazy brackets; plus there were so many to choose from. In my first month of printing with this printer, I had heard many people were shattering their acrylic parts, so I made these to have on hand in case that happened to me.

By the way, I've since upgraded to full aluminium brackets, and I HIGHLY recommend that. I ordered from taralu.net

EDIT (07/03/2018): Added low profile Z-motor brackets, to allow the gantry to move all the way up. Thanks to @japree for noticing that.

comments.text:
I printed the L brackets today and I noticed that the parts aren't stiff enough. So I printed them again with 100% Infill but the brackets weren't stiffer than the original ones either. I began to measure the original brackets and compared them to the printed ones. I noticed that the original brackets were 1 mm thicker than the printed ones. I hope that you could adjust this. I printed them again by adjusting the scaling in Z direction. The brackets are now 5.2mm thick and stiffer than the original ones. I would recommend the following settings for Simplify3D for maximum strength of the brackets:
Perimeter: 3
Solid Top / Bottom Layer: 3
Infill: 100% (Rectilinear Type)
Layer Height: Minimum 0.3mm

description.text:
Parts for improving the Duchess board game table made by boardgametables.com.

Support Bracket

The support bracket is designed to screw underneath the table and pull the plywood vault bottom down flush with the support braces. This was to eliminate bowing in the vault plywood floor, and to lock everything together to avoid having a loose feeling vault floor that made noise when setting pieces and cards down. You will want about 8 of them. Use #6 screws 1/2" length to pull it all together.

Cup Shim

The cup shim is designed to replace the nut and washer provided with the cup holders. The intent is to provide a larger flat surface for the cup holder to rotate against with respect to the bottom of the side rail and avoid tilting of the cup holder in rotation, scratching the surface. Since there isn't a lock nut any longer, I'd recommend a little Locktite on the 6mm hex screw to prevent it from rotating and working it's way lose over time. Also pre-drilling the hole slightly larger than the 6mm screw will help the shim rotate around the screw without the screw trying to rotate.

These designs have not been thoroughly tested, and may be refined, but I have installed these on my table. So far I am happy with the results.

title: Atomic Playset
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hey Kids!

Wanna be a mad scientist and create your own Molecules? Atomic Playset is the print for you! Combine common atoms to create new and exciting molecules! H2CO3 makes your nose tingle (Carbonated Water) but H2SO4 will burn you (Sulfuric Acid)!

I think the best thing you can ever do is derive from yourself. I had a lot of fun working on the Molecules Thing, but something was really missing. Wouldn't it be cool if you could just print a few atoms and stick them together to make whatever you wanted? Atoms were born!

I adapted the original code to create sockets in the atoms and rods to connect them. Print as many as you like in whatever colors you like. Using different colors will add emphasis.

This one is deduced to my neighbors, Laurie and Andrew. Thank you for your inspiration.

Some of my favorite molocules:
H2O - Water
CO2 - Carbon Dioxide
NO2 - Nitrous Oxide - Laughing Gas
O2 - Oxygen
NaCl - Sodium Chloride - Salt
H2CO3 - Carbonic Acid - Carbonated Water
H2SO4 - Sulfuric Acid
C12H22O11 - Sucrose - Sugar
C8H10N4O2 - Caffeine (Coffee)

To read these formulas, C12 refers to the number of Carbon Atoms, in this case 12. CO2 refers to 1 Carbon Atom and 2 Oxygen Atoms.

7/4/17: Update V2 Version Rods. Tapered to make them easier to insert, and a spacer in the middle to stop them from going in too far.

SD40-2 project for 1/8 scale or 1.5 inch scale live steam. there are 138 printable parts

property of Dakota C (me) enjoy!

UPDATE

Added file: "sd40 exploded printable"

this file is the same as the other printable one but the parts are separated as seen in the picture so that they can be split up in your slicer. I use cura, right click and select "split object into parts" this will allow you to print in parts.

thingiverse will not let me upload the sketch up file sorry.

Printer:

prusa mendel i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

any

Infill:

20% works for me

Notes:

this was done in google sketchup, the file named "printable" is modified to be scaled down as far a 0 scale or 0.15 of its current scale, i designed this to be cut from steel and made in 1/8 scale live steam. the original file is the colored one in Burlington northern paint. not everything is exact as things were changed to be easily printed and easily made from steel.

most parts can be scaled and printed as is, some of the small parts such as hoses need to be scaled in the z direction to be at least 4 layers at .3 resolution unless your printer can handle smaller prints. the main concern is warping when pulling from the print bed.

i printed a few strips of the handrail provided in the printable file and cut them to the desired length then bent them to fit where i wanted.

doors were printed separate and glued on, as well as the vents, i printed an extra 2 vents and put them over the mid section loovers that are directly behind the cab.

the trucks will fit together tightly accept the axles. and the wheels holes need to be drilled out to 1/8 inch for O scale for the axles to slip inside. the motors and mounts do not need to be printed but i did.

the deck as is will press fit together in O scale. you will want to adjust the tab is printing smaller or larger.

yes. the ditch lights will print.

the gas tank can be used to glue the 2 deck sections together.

I did NOT print the breaks as they were too small.

if you want the sketchup file i will email them to you per request.
comment if you have any questions!
Super glue it together!

I used google sketch up and various pictures online to get a basic shape of the trucks and deck, once i got the deck and below built i "borrowed" the cab file from the internet (dont remember the site but if its yours please take credit) then used the cab to design the rear end. I have an N scale mode ive used for proportions and guestimated some details such as the vents, fans, and doors. the plow and handrails were stolen from a file on grabcad at this link: https://grabcad.com/library/sd40-2-1 I have to give him credit for that.

other than the cab, handrails, and snowplow, this was my design. Enjoy

title: ASUS DirectCUII GTX 770 GPU Retention Bracket

description.text:
It's a GPU anti-sag retention bracket for my ASUS GTX 770 DirectCUII 2GB. I tried to match its aesthetic to that of a DirectCUII-style cooler.

Note that the "tip" of it is raised to accommodate for the bevel on this specific GPU cooler - thus:

FOR ANY DIFFERENT GRAPHICS CARD OR COOLER, YOU MAY HAVE TO SAND DOWN THE TIP TO LEVEL YOUR CARD PROPERLY.

Some ASUS DirectCUII graphics cards have similar or identical coolers to the GTX 770.
These include the following:

-GTX 670
-GTX 680 (Dual-slot version)
-GTX 760 Dragon
-HD 7850 Dragon
-HD 7870 V2 (I think)

Printer:

ANet A8

Rafts:

No

No

0.1mm

100%

Notes:

This print is really easy. I printed it at 0.1mm and 100% infill, but it would probably print at 0.2mm and even 20% infill. No promises though.

It doesn't take much plastic to print - I believe it was around 2-3m of 1.75mm PLA for me.

I painted it matte black to make it look cleaner, but it works and looks fine without any paint.

description.text:
Calibrate your dual extruder XY offsets with minimum effort and material waste.

Use only around 50mm of each material.

First eyeball the offsets so the extruders fall in around 1mm range when switching between them (use T0 and T1 command).

One method I found useful is to stick a piece of blu-tack in the middle of the bed, lower your extruder to make a mark on the blu-tack, then switch to the second extruder and make another mark. Then you can measure the XY distances of the 2 marks and use them as initial offset values.

Load both objects into your slicer without any offset. Assign each to a different extruder and print. They should be able to bind together without any overlap if your extruder offset is close enough.

After printing the object, find the short line that align best with the line on its opposite side, count how many short lines are on its left and right. If it's 10 vs 10, that means a perfect alignment. If not, change the offset value by 0.1 * (numOfShortLineOnLeft - 10), then print again to verify.

After finishing X axis, rotate the objects by 90 degrees to calibrate Y axis.

title: Thule Chariot CX trailer - narrow pushbar steel tube connector idea

description.text:
We have a thule chariot for our little girl.

I didn't like the original pushbar, it's very wide, and produces a lot of rattle while cycling.
It also makes the trailer big and we have a bit of a small house.

This design connect both tubes with an M5 so it the plastic fails the bolt should still keep things together adding to the safety.
It should be noted that thule doesn't allow you to modify the trailer and I'm in no way responsible, this is very much "as is".

You need 19mm and 22.2mm tubing for this, I used 4130.
for the nut holder/insert I used 19x0.9, if you use thicker tubing this may require a different insert.
Use soft washers (nylon or so) to avoid damaging anything, also, don't overthighten and use locknuts, be carefull when drilling the holes, my second hole was a bit off.

title: Geeetech G2S pro print cooling duct

description.text:
For installing of a 50mm blower fan to cool prints.

To be able to make room for the print cooling fan, the original 30mm hotend cooling fan has to be moved to the other side of the spider, to sit next to the probe pin. Print the attached fan-mount.stl to install the original 30mm fan to the spare mounting hole.

Use a 16mm m3 screw and m3 nut to attach the fan duct to the spider, then insert the 50mm fan to it. I was intending to use a zip tie to secure the fan but it seems the duct is tight enough to secure it without any other help.

description.text:
These were designed to work with another item here on thinaverse -
"DJI F450 F550 Flamewheel Long Leg Extensions - 5mm Thick" They are used to attach your quadcopter to an engine "runup" pad so it doesn't take off while undergoing testing or maintenance. No more dings in the ceiling. Print 4 of these, attached them to something heavier than your quad can lift, insert a nail in each one to connect the quad to the "runup" pad, and then test to your hearts content knowing the beast will not lift off. This was designed in sketchup so i included that file in case you want to modify it.

comments.text:
Thanks for posting this. I've remixed it so that it will fit on stock F450 landing legs, and made sure I gave you a shout out.
Thanks again!

this print used for chinese cnc3040 spindle 300w upgrading to 1.5kw

i feel my chinese cnc3040 spindle is weak to carving hard wood or aluminium
so i upgrade the spindle 300w to 1.5kw

some people cut the part and welding spindle clamp to z zxis carriage.
this method is not cost and not damage to original parts.
so i use this 3d print to replace it. simple and cheap.

80% infill print is very firm to resist almost 10kg in my experience(bicycle stand)
i guess (1.5kw spindle+ spindle clamp + carriage plate) weight is under 5kg

check the z carriage picture

(this model linear bearing size 12mm ; LML 12UU)

McKnight's designs proved to be perfect for this. In order to maintain the convenience of Platinumrob's Fan Swivel, I had to Frankenstein in his Swivelmount.

Since I had some diffculties with adjusting my nozzle height (it ended up too short), I shortened McKnight's cooler as well and included it with this Thing.

"The Lords of the Beyond after being banished left behind a large strip of devastated land, with ghost towns, buildings, temples and a whole range of localities. Rumors that in these places existed treasures, weapons and a whole range of fantastic things, began to arrive in the ears of the people of our world.

Individuals in search of fame and fortune have decided to enter these cursed lands in search of these prizes. Organized in small groups, they enter these lands and there they face dangers. This is the premise of Scavengers, a skirmish game in the devastated lands, where you lead a group of adventurers in search of fame and fortune.

Extracted from Alabar Chronicle´s, a Scavenger Guide to Our World"

Introduction

Scavengers is a table top miniature war game for fighting skirmishes with fantasy/steampunk figures. Two players fight a small scale combat with five to ten miniatures on each side (a hero and your henchmen). The game is easy to learn and play, though there is enough depth that it will take time and experience to master.

The game was designed around three core premises.

a) You can download our 3D models or use any miniatures in their collection. Thus, the game is not specifically designed to any particular manufacturer or company. But if you like to help the game dev, please download our models! (They are free and paid...)

b) It is important that the miniatures on the table be the focus of the game. In the end, miniature gaming should be about miniatures (and fun!)

c) A large background - We´ll develop new units, histories and game scenarios. But we need your help, sending suggestions to improve the game!

I hope you like our game and have fun! Ahh, an important thing: this is the basic core rules, our idea is releasing other books to improve the game!

This is a rocks set, for your game table! Our gaming site is coming with our core book, game lore and a lot of new things!

Note: You don´t need a base for it.

title: WD Elements Portable U3 - Transportation Case

description.text:
My brother and I often send hard drives back an forth, using postal service, to exchange photos, etc.

Recently his harddrive got damaged by postage handling.

This will protect his new HDD.

Inside measurements in mm.: 22 x 83 x 108. Outside: 51 x 108 x 125.
All thicknesses in model are 1,2mm

I printed with zero infill, and a print width of 0,6mm, to make it fast.
Printed in PLA at 220 degrees c. for great layer adhesion.

My own print quality settings were fast but ugly, as you can see. :)

Made built-in support for inner part. Easy to brake off.

Hope you can use it, or get inspired. :)

Happy printing,
Torben

description.text:
FPV camera with video transmitter mount

Features:

  • 2 in 1! Saves space for super clean build!
  • M2 mounting hole with 19mm spacing for RunCam Micro Swift.
  • Canted mounting slot for Eachine VTX03 video transmitter with front facing channel display and easy button access.

Notes:

My test print was printed in PLA, 0.15mm layer height with 30% infill.
Feels sturdy on hand and bends quite a lot without breaking.
Support is recommended since the angle is a bit extreme for the thin arms, you may want to print slow.

ABS or even nylon is recommended if you printer can handle them, you gotta crash the quad a lot, right?

Cheers

fudgeFactor = 0.5

Those of you who use a Parrot Skycontroller 1 to fly a Bebop quadcopter know that the emergency button can be accidentally touched easily. And when you hit the emergency button, it switches off all motors of your Bebop. So wherever it is flying at that time, it falls down. I know from experience that that is usually not a preferred place! This emergency button guard slides over the right handlebar of the Skycontroller. It lifts the top surface a bit to prevent pressing the switch casually.

Just click the guard on the handlebar, it stays well in place. I printed mine from PLA. If you want to tighten it more, use a piece of double sided tape or edit the FreeCAD design and adjust whatever you like.

description.text: Construction is snap together! Glue and/or trimming might help with durability, but don't seem to be necessary when printed on a MakerBot Replicator; friction is enough to keep parts together. Seej is a tabletop wargame based around 3D printing. Check out http://s33j.net for rules and more information. At a minimum, you'll need this pennon, a siege engine like the Zheng3 Penny Ballista: http://www.zheng3.com/2012/05/22/zheng3-penny-ballista/ And some bloxen: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23620 You can also search Thingiverse for Things with the seej tag. Be sure to check Zheng3.com for updates. If Twitter's more your thing then follow Zheng3 at http://twitter.com/Zheng3_Jim

description.text:
This is a remix of two great designs which I very much like.The Hex Design Toolless Mounting Spool Holder and the adjustable Filament Spool Holder. I really wanted a spool holder that could be easily adjusted while sitting atop the Prusa frame. So I have created a remix of these two designs to give an adjustable holder which clips to the top frame, uses bearings with sleeve rollers to ensure your filament spools stays in place and glides in a straight line.

This new design is easy to print as it is printed in separate parts, with minimal supports required. You will need the following hardware to fix the parts.

4x M3 12 - 14mm socket head bolts
4 x M3 hex nuts
4 x 608zz bearings

Simply Push the vertical arms into the base connecting the lugs with the appropriate holes. Next, place the nuts into the slots on each arm (x2 per arm) , Prusa style :), and bolt through the base. Then simply slide the end part onto the base, screw in the screw thread with thumbwheel and attach the rollers with 608ZZ bearings inserted. That's it.

Now, when you need to adjust the width of the bearing rollers for different width spools simply turn the thumbwheel until the rollers are at the requied width. The slot cutout on the front edge of the base is so you can add a filament guide. It has been specifically designed to accept this filament guide, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2341182, but many other will fit. When preparing for print please ensure you add required supports for the under base holes and accomodating lugs on the arms. This will ensure they print with the correct shape to engage. You should find that the liugs engage with a push and, whilst this will likely be enough to attach and hold the arms to the base, you still need to use the nuts and bolts.

And if you decide not to use on the frame then simple remove the side bracket arms and place on the desk, using the bolt holes to screw to the surface or simply use sticky tape.

I hope you enjoy it and please let me have any comments. Thanks.

03/06: it appears the screw threaded part was somehow incorrect rotation (mirrored). The corrected STL has now been uploaded.

22/06: I have added 3 additional parts which allow you to join multiple spool holders together when using on a flat surface (not connected to the Prusa frame). For example:

If you want to create a dual spool holder print 2 end connectors and 1 mid connector.
If you want to print a quad spool holder print 2 end connectors and 3 mid connectors.

The connectors simply push fit into the holes in the flat base of the spool holder. If you wish to physically connect the joined parts to your flat surface use the end connectors with fix holes and screw to the surface using 2 suitable screws at each end.

UPDATE: I have just added a new pair of brackets to enable mounting this holder on a 3030 extrusion frame. These brackets only use the rear bolts to hold the main part to the brackets.

UPDATE: I have added v2 versions of base, slider and rollers which include spigots for better grip on the rollers.

UPDATE: I have added a v3 of the base which includes a wider filament guide cutout to assist when using narrow spools.

UPDATE: Added a custom version of the filament guide for Haribo users.

comments.text: Yeah, I'll do that and it will hopefully solve the issue. I wanted to mention it here as well though, I'm probably not the only one who's encountered this.
comments.author: Aero3D

comments.text: Thanks.  I've printed hundreds of hours on 2 Mk2s with these holders and never had an issue so think it depends very much on the bearings used and how free running they are.  Also, I guess the different tolerances on filaments will also play a part as to how free or stiff the bearings are when inserted.  Too stiff and it will affect print quality.  Make sure also you are using a filament guide as this will also add some additional friction on the filament path and also prevent the filament from jumping off the spool.

title: center speaker adapter frame w212 mercedes e-class
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a frame to support a center speaker in a mercedes e-class type w212 (or s212).
My printed one is without the soft edges, which I added later for a better fit. It fits very tight. If your print is a little too big, you will have to make the long edge fitting.
It supports a 2.4 " speaker (like mine: Ground Zero GZ PM 60 SQ) For further information check (in german): http://www.motor-talk.de/forum/aktion/PostJump.html?postId=39373741
Made a sample from cardboard and then modeled in autocad

title: DJI Mavic Pro Adapter for Moverio Epson BT300
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Epson Moverio BT-300 controller will securely snap into these cradles. Two iterations, the longer version protects the cable attachment in the back of the Epson controller. I suspect this may be a point of cable breaks if you use a strap around the neck to keep the controller level. The short version is more compact otherwise the same. Designed so that you can leave all assembled and switch the BT-300 controller easily on and off. I printed this in PETG. ABS should be fine but PLA is probably not flexible enough. Enjoy Life.

There is now a case for this with the two controllers attached. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2389371

title: Cokin filter mount for the samyang/rokinon 7.5mm f3.8 fisheye

description.text:
I wanted a neutral density filter for the 7.5mm f3.8 that I use on my blackmagic pocket cinema.
As this lens is a fish there aren't many options.
I always liked the cokin filters but couldn't find a fish eye mount.

This allows you to use any cokin filter on the lens.

Use M3x40 to srew this together.

There is some room for improvements, but it works

title: INTEX inlet to standard 1.5 inch pool hose

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/9FhVap8YLfD

I used MERCJR's base object, and added a 1.5" female hose connection, so a standard pool hose can be attached to the fitting. this still screws onto the inlet piece for INTEX pool pumps.

I can now use my standard pool vacuum.

I also included a recess for an O-Ring, if someone wants it.

I printed and tested it with PLA, which seems okay for the moment, but i'll likely re-print it with something more durable, like ABS, when i get a chance.

author: sum511

print_settings.Notes:: A brim may be useful to avoid warping

description.text:
Sometimes i like to place a laptop on the ground, with the screen almost flush with it, so that i can look at it from above. So here is a laptop stand for that. The screen ends up in a 30° angle from the horizontal.

There are two variants, one for thin laptops where the hinge is arranged so there is no step when it’s open, and those that have a step there.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

300 µm

Infill:

5 %

Notes:

Mirror the provided STL in your slice so that you get a pair.
I generally like to print with low infil and many perimeters and top layers, but set it up to your taste. 300 µm layer height should be fine.

A brim may be useful to avoid warping
You need two standard sized pencils. Tear off any erasers, and saw of the the tips, when they came sharpened.

This is slightly parametric. With a bit of work you can adapt this to your laptop and your print bed. For that i have included the FreeCAD files. They include a spreadsheet called “sizes”. Change values there, check the shape still works, turn it into a mesh and export it.

There is also some design history available at my github repo.

author: guitaman

description.text: I created this sword, Xiphos, the iconic weapon of the ancient Greeks, for my own enjoyment and figured that this might be something useful to you guys since there are currently no xiphos in Thingiverse :(. I used Autodesk Inventor to create this sword. Feel free to download the files can try to print one out. The clearances are tuned for FDM printers so that the fitting should be just about right. I designed this based on my M3D Micro printer. The Micro should be able to print all things in the scale of 0.85 while all models should be well fitting onto a regular FDM printer platform such as a Makerbot/ Flashforge. Unfortunately, my printer is now in its downtime. I haven't got a chance to print the whole thing out. However, I am so excited to see how it looks in real life. So please feel free to make one yourself and post your photos! Thanks.
02/07/2017 Update: Printed with 0.8 scaling factor. First glued with Loctite 401 glue and then Z-poxy for the surfaces. I shall paint the sword later.

title: Taranis Q X7 M9 Gimbal fit

description.text:
UPDATE 4-6-2017: New ring added that better follows the shape of the case.

This is my implementation for the M9 gimbal to fit in the Taranis Q X7.
It is based on the work of Teramax.

To print the left ring, you have to mirror one 180 dec left-right in your slicer

One of the main differences is the curved edges of the ring and the alternative ring that has variable hight and that does not sit in the way of your finders that much.

I have placed the gimbals in the same way as they where in the Taranis 9D. This make all directions reversed, but that can be corrected in the input tab of open TX.
As an alternative you can rotate the gimbals 180dec but that required you to take away some plastic on the module bay.

We have a steel door where we put a curtain on with magnetic curtain rod holders. One of them broke so I took the magnet out of the broken piece and got my calipers out and did some measuring to come up with my own version which when completed holds the magnet I took out of the broken one and used 3m double stick tape to secure the magnet in the new holder. I painted the new one to kind of match the old one and it all worked out well. One could find their own magnet and print a set and have their own way of placing a curtain on a steel door or where it may work. I printed with 20% infill and used very light supports which pulled right out of the area where the magnet mounts.

description.text:
Credit to tilden for the original file,

Changed orientation of the indicator mark and modified to be a snug fit on a 1/4" post.

Printed on a Anet A8 printer with 20% infill in abs.

Original item can be found here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:360798

I liked the business card holder ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:137636 ), but it isn't printable. My version isn't perfect, but can be printed. It isn't really a re-mix per say, but it is in spirit (I started from scratch on my version). Should work without any scaling for standard sized business cards, don't overfill it or it could become top-heavy (Perhaps consider taping it down)
Removed some non-manifolds.

This was an practical excercise because I worked with Sketchup and now I check out Fusion 360.
The daughter of my friend had a fidget spinner but her brother broke it.
So why not combine a cad practice with making a girl smile?
I think my nozzle offsets have to be adjusted (and retraction settings).
Have fun with this spinner and if you print one, show me a make.

update:
I forgot to mention that it's made for 608 bearings meaning 22mm diameter and 7mm thick.

This is an Elephant fidget Spinner I designed. It is designed to be on the smaller side so it should fit in kids hands, but adults can play with it too!

This requires 608ZZ bearings.

The bearing covers also have a small lip to prevent the covers from accidentally touching the bearing and slowing it down. You can squeeze these covers firmly without deforming them and slowing the bearings.

title: Braided Galton Board - Probabilities with String

description.text:
This is intended to be an intuitive demonstration of the Central Limit theorem. The Galton board is a standard way to show this with falling balls. However instead we use string, and have each possible path represented with one thread, and we can see at a glance which locations are probable.

The dowels are 12.5mm. I just hammered them into the lasercut wood, but you might want to glue if the tolerances are different for your lasercutter.

The string is 1mm builders cord, but anything should be fine.

I found it very difficult to thread without making a mistake. The strategy I ended up using was to hold the prevoius thread in my left hand and the next thread in my right. By jiggling my left hand I saw the old thread bounce, which gave a good reminder of where I was in the sequence, and hence to put the new thread in the right spot.

title: Fireflash from Thunderbirds - early work in progress
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Very early work, please don't even think about printing!

I'll keep updating as I add more detail. The intention is the final thing will print in lots of different parts and clip/glue together just like my Thunderbird 1.

If you want to play with the code, see all the other libraries listed and stick them in your library path. The URLs are at the top of FF.scad

Update: 2017-06-03 - added tail centre pod and engine supports.
Update 2017-06-04 - added engines. I didn't even use any splines!
Update 2017-06-05 - improved engines and fixed some odd rendering issues.
Update 2017-06-05 - added canard wings. More spliny goodness.
Update 2017-06-06 - added engine winglets, fixed centre pod, tweaked canard/body interface, some code cleanups.
Update 2017-06-10 - added "fin" coming forwards from the bridge, cleaned up code more to avoid self intersections and to split to separate files. No source upload for this lot as I'm still beating on it all and I also had to hack some libraries.
Update: 2017-07-02 - added wings and pods, fixed all CGAL errors, added slicing for printing to FF_Tail but still lots to do. Also tweaked pretty much every part of the design to get it to better match the "real thing", and added ability to select a fixed camera view to make matching to pictures easier. Split BaseBody to separate file.
Update: 2017-07-16 - added detail to engines, printed tail+pod+engines but have now changed how the pod sits on the bridge so all changed and being redone. She's starting to look good!
Update: 2017-07-20 - added pictures of a test print of tail with new splitting, and there is also a body "fragment" tacked on. Very happy with how it looks and will upload new source and STLs in a few days. Next job is slice engine winglets, add detail to tail, and start to design wing hinges.
Update: 2017-08-01 - Sliced winglets, added text to tail, printed new parts, and picture uploaded. Will upload new source once text tested.
Update: 2017-08-11 - Added more detail to tail and added cockpit windows. New source and STLs uploaded. I haven't printed new bits yet so no pictures.

Update: 2017-09-09 Body and wings now all sliced, so starting on some test prints as I slowly add fixing pegs and update the make file.

title: MakerBot 2 & 2X new improved corner tool holder

description.text:
I improved this original design to solve a problem of where to store the Dial Indicator when not in use. The pegs are 12.25mm & 8.25mm
The holes in the Dial Indicator and the corner tool holder are 13 & 9 mm. I added the piece on the side of the original design to have a surface for the Dial Indicator holder to be supported with.
I printed with 30% infill I glued the pegs on with Loctite Clear Powergrab.
